text.p: Italian debt markets ended up after shadowing Bunds for the session but managing to outperform the German market overall.
Brokers said high yielders in general had outperformed and Italy itself had seen good domestic buying.

Expectations for a cut in the Italian discount rate seemed to have been pushed further out to next week or even early June, although analysts said judging the timing of a possible easing was extremely hard.
Linda Glover, senior broker at HSBC in London, said the expectation the Bank of Italy would cut eventually remained.

"There is the tantalising prospect of a rate cut," Glover said. But since the central bank had not moved straight after encouraging preliminary inflation data earlier this week the feeling was "Why bother just before the French elections."
She said the Bank of Italy could even wait as long as early June, after both this weekend's first round of French polling and the second round on June 1.

The prospect of a possible victory by the opposition French Socialist party has potential to unnerve financial markets who would be concerned about subsequent progress towards a single European currency.
As a result, analysts say the Bank of Italy may be waiting to see how voting turns out.

In addition, the central bank presents its annual report next week and the government is due to unveil its three-year economic plan, both of which are factors which analysts say could make the bank wait.
London and U.S. markets are closed on Monday and brokers said players seemed to have prefered to go home short.
